subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 10th January 2020: Dow briefly tops 29k; stocks slip after jobs report miss, wage pace slowing
content:
• * SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar flat, Crude down.
  • * REAR VIEW: NFP misses expectations, wage growth slows; Canadian labour report beats expectations; US imposes more Iran sanctions; Kashkari sees rates on hold for the foreseeable future, next move a cut.
  • * WEEK IN FOCUS: MON: UK GDP Estimate, US CB Employment Trends. TUE: US CPI, EIA STEO, US Earnings Season Unofficially Begins, US Democratic Debate. WED: EZ Industrial Production, US PPI, OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report. THU: US Retail Sales, SARB & CBRT Monetary Policy Decision; ECB Minutes (December); IEA Monthly Report. FRI: Chinese GDP, Industrial Production and Retail Sales, EZ CPI (Final), US University of Michigan Sentiment, US Building Permits, Housing Starts, Industrial Production, JOLTS, BoK Monetary Policy Decision. To download the report, please click here.
  • * CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY: PREVIEWING ECB minutes, CBRT, SARB and BOK rate decisions. REVIEWING Fedspeak, BOE’s Carney, Riksbank minutes. To download the report, please click here.

* US JOBS REPORT (DEC): 145k jobs were added to the US economy in December, missing the consensus 165k. The two-month revision was -14k. For last year as a whole, 2.108mln jobs were added to the US economy; the new trend rates: 3-month at 184k (prev. 205k), 6-month at 189k (prev. 196k) and 12-month at 176k (prev. 184k). Meanwhile, average hourly earnings metrics disappointed, falling sub 3.0% Y/Y for the first time since July 2018, at 2.9% Y/Y (expected unchanged 3.1%). The jobless rate was unchanged at 3.5%, as expected, although the U6 measure fell to 6.7% from 6.9%, while participation was unchanged. "Stepping back from the noise, the key point here is that payroll growth is performing far better than implied by a host of leading indicators in late summer and fall," Pantheon Macroeconomics writes, "businesses appear to have over-estimated the real impact of the trade war, distorting their survey responses." PM does not expect the Q4 trend rates to change in Q1, and if it is correct, then the jobless rate will continue to decline, possibly hitting 3.00% by 2020-end. "No one at the Fed thinks the NAIRU is less than 3%, so under normal circumstances we’d expect to see the Fed talking about higher rates, not easing," PM says, "that won’t happen ahead of the election but we cannot see why the Fed would ease if the recent payroll gains are sustained." Finally, Pantheon says that although this appears to be an inconsequential payroll report, nothing could be further from the truth: "we cannot stress enough that three straight months of substantial overshoots against the surveys means that the surveys are wrong; labor demand remains strong enough to continue pushing down the unemployment rate."

* FED: Fed’s Kashkari (voter, dove) said the December employment situation report suggests that the economy is slowing. Kashkari would support a rate cut if jobs growth continues to weaken, inflation stays low, inflation expectations slip. He sees rates on hold for the foreseeable future, and sees the next move as a cut, rather than a hike. He supports an SRF, and said it would allow the Fed to have a smaller balance sheet.

* CANADA JOBS REPORT (DEC): The Canadian job metrics surprised to the upside, seeing 35.2k added to the economy in December, above the expected 25k. The unemployment rate fell by more than expected, to 5.6% from 5.9% (exp. 5.8%). These were the jobs numbers we were all hoping for following November's ugly employment report, RBC said, with the overall headcount retracing half the previous month's decline (even more if you exclude transitory factors from November) and more importantly the unemployment rate erased much of November's 0.4 percentage point increase (which was easily the largest in a decade). In terms of the policy implications, RBC says the data will not necessarily keep the BOC on the sidelines, however: "GDP data for H2 2019 has been disappointing, and a slightly softer labour market over that period suggests transitory factors are not solely to blame for sub-trend growth," and "having cleared the employment hurdle, we're now looking ahead to Monday's Business Outlook Survey to see how Canadian firms are dealing with a still-uncertain global backdrop."

* IRAN: US Secretary of State Pompeo and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin confirmed additional sanctions would be slapped on Iran, focussing on individuals and on steel and iron manufacturers/entities. Seventeen of the largest steel and iron manufacturers in Iran were sanctioned in an effort to further hamper the Iranian economy; eight senior Iranian officials were also sanctioned and Mnuchin echoed comments from US President Trump, that economic sanctions will continue unless they adhere to the US requests; however, the US will issue waivers to those helping with the Iran jet cash probe. Iran today announced that it would Saturday announce the cause of the crash. Geopolitical consultancy Stratfor highlights that if US chooses to further pressure Iran, it could increase its scrutiny of foreign firms that engage in business activities with the region. Pompeo announced that there was no doubt that Iran had the full intention of killing US forces in the missile attack, despite some speculation that it was a targeted attack to show response but not escalate the tensions by killing troops. On the withdrawal of US troops, he announced the US is happy to continue talks with Iraq regarding the right structure.

* KUDLOW: NEC Director Kudlow confirmed the US-China Phase One deal has been translated and authenticated, noting everything is in place, and that there will be a factsheet released on Wednesday following the deal’s signing, citing USTR Lighthizer. He noted the Phase One part could equate to 40% or 50% of the entire deal which has the capacity to add half a point of growth for this year, in the event the Phase One deal goes ahead as planned. On the specifics, Kudlow highlighted that tremendous progress was made on IP, with some progress made on the transfer of technology. Kudlow stated that China will exceed USD 200bln worth of agri-purchases over two-years, citing volume and capabilities of products to be sold has been vastly expanded when questioned about the practicality of this figure. In the event that disputes occur, if they appear and are not resolved, the US would take proportionate action, and Kudlow said the dispute resolution process will be a multi-layered one. On Phase Two,  Kudlow said the time frame is up to the President, however overnight, China’s Global Times, citing an expert close to the government, announced that November after the election will be too far away for a Phase Two deal. Meanwhile, on the USMCA, Kudlow stated the median estimate is to add 0.75ppts of growth to the US, with many more additional jobs. Regarding Section 232 auto-tariffs on the EU, Kudlow confirmed no action has been taken yet, and added that it remains a Presidential affair, though the US remains in constant negotiation with the EU.

* AUSTRALIA RETAIL SALES (NOV): Retail sales picked up by 0.9% beating estimates for a 0.4% print, the previous was also revised higher to 0.1% from a flat reading in October. The strong report boosted AUD overnight and led it to outperform its G10 peers. However, analysts at UBS have highlighted the risk of Black Friday which bought consumer spending forward a month. UBS also note that its December performance of services index collapsed after a high reading in November, which hints at a a retracement in December’s data.

* WTI (G20) SETTLES USD 0.52 LOWER AT USD 59.04; BRENT (H20) SETTLES USD 0.39 LOWER AT USD 64.98. Energy prices had a choppy day of trade again to end the week, with participants balancing a weak US jobs report, Iranian sanctions and book squaring ahead of the weekend. Prices reached their peak in the European session - Brent (H0) and WTI (G0) reached highs of 65.66 and 59.78, respectively – before treading lower as US participants came to their desks, as well as a disappointing US jobs report which weighed on growth sentiment. The complex found some strength later in the session on the US announcing its wide-encompassing sanctions on Iran, although the strength proved short-lived, marking the first weekly loss for the crude benchmarks since November last year. Elsewhere, the US Baker Hughes rig count saw oil rigs -11 at 659, natgas rigs -4 at 119 and total rigs -15 at 781.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.29% at 3265, NDZ -0.26% at 8997, Dow -0.46% at 28823; SECTORS: Communication -0.3%, consumer discretionary -0.5%, consumer staples -0.1%, energy -0.6%, financials -0.8%, health care 0.0%, industrials -0.7%, IT -0.2%, materials -0.4%, telecoms -0.2%, utilities +0.2%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Financials (XLF) underperformed on the back of lower yields, which supported the Real Estate sector (XLRE), Industrials (XLI) and Consumer Discretionary (XLY) were also worst hit, with the disappointing jobs report weighing on sentiment, whilst the defensive Utilities (XLU) and Health Care (XLV) outperformed. GrubHub (GRUB) reversed recent gains as it refuted reports that it was considering a sale. Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) traded in the green after providing preliminary Q4 revenue above expectations. Nvidia (NVDA) was a top performer after a “top pick” mention at Citi. Skyworks (SWKS) and Qorvo (QRVO) fared better following Mizuho upgrading both stocks to Buy on optimism for the 5G handset outlook. Lumentum (LITE) suffered on a downgrade at Raymond James to Outperform from Strong Buy on valuation. SYNNEX (SNX) surged after a strong earnings report and announcing its plans to split into two separately traded public companies. KB Home (KBH) bucked the real estate strength and took a haircut after disappointing revenue. L Brands (LB) strength continued for a second session as more analysts warmed to the notion that strategic action could be imminent, with the weak holiday sales serving as a tipping point. Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) surged on an extended collaboration with Bristol-Myers (BMY). Luckin Coffee (LK) traded lower after it raised the number of shares offered in its secondary offering that also priced.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H20) SETTLE 6 TICKS HIGHER AT 129-02+. The curve bull-flattened on Friday, with yields in the front of the curve on slightly lower, while 30s had fallen by almost 5bps. The employment situation report was mildly disappointing, with the headline missing expectations, and the pace of wage growth easing to under 3.0% Y/Y, bringing buying interest. A Raymond James strategist said that for the bond market, this was a positive number, especially when it comes to wage inflation; "the subtle drop in the number of hours worked," he said, "and the lower-than-expected average hourly earnings number is good for fixed income. While today's data may not result in a big move down in rates, it certainly doesn’t support a big move higher either."

* FX: USD was offered after the US jobs report and saw an afternoon low at 97.30, with lower yields likely adding to pressure. EURUSD broke 1.11 to the upside, buoyed by a lower USD, as well as EUR 800mln of option expiries rolling off at today’s NY cut. GBP continued to pare in the aftermath of BOE governor Carney’s dovish speech on Thursday, testing 1.31 to the upside after the US jobs report, though the move was short-lived. USDCAD took a double hit after the strong Canada jobs report and weaker US jobs report. USDCAD found support at 1.3025 (yesterday’s low was 1.3026), and now technicians eye 1.3008, the January 2nd and 3rd high. USDJPY continued to eye the December high of 109.73 in the early part of the session however the cross pared after US NFP’s, as rate differentials moved in favour of the yen, though technicians note the cross remains above 109.50. XAU was buoyed post-NFP, but remained well-off recent best levels, as tensions in the Middle East eases. AUD outperformed among G10 FX after strong November retail sales, even though analysts warn of a pull back next month. NZD failed to catch-up completely against its antipodean counterpart, although was supported after today’s US NFP. EMFX generally firmer against the buck; ZAR however was under pressure after state utility Eskom’s chair resigned, followed by further loadshedding this weekend. BRL pared some of the prior day losses amid a firmer December IPCA inflation report. MXN was also firmer as the fall in industrial output slowed, while TRY was rather flat against the buck, although slightly firmer amid the continued fall in oil prices.

subject: Weekly FX Wrap: Buck labours post-NFP, but still on track to rack up net gains
content:
USD

A relatively rare US payroll miss, and an even more unusual soft headline in conjunction with benign wages, knocked the Dollar off stride, but has not derailed the recovery as the DXY remains on course to end the week some 100 ticks above worst levels within a 96.537-97.586 range. The Greenback gleaned some traction from final Markit services and composite PMIs before a much better non-manufacturing ISM compared to manufacturing survey and a stellar ADP survey that raised the NFP bar. However, the real turning point for the Buck and index came after Iran’s much less aggressive than anticipated or feared retaliation to the assassination of a senior IRGC general given Tehran’s initial verbal threats. The upshot, no further reaction from the US beyond sanctions and a de-escalation of ME conflict concerns to the benefit of the Usd vs safer havens amidst an overall revival in risk appetite when President Trump instructed troops to take out the aforementioned top Iranian Elite Force operative.

AUD 

Friday’s major outperformer, albeit still lower on the week as a whole between 0.6957-0.6850 parameters, after a 2nd successive upside data surprise (retail sales following on from trade). Aud/Usd is back within striking distance of the 0.6900 handle after eclipsing the 200 DMA (0.6895) and has just reclaimed 1.0400+ status vs the Kiwi, as NZD/Usd remains top-heavy above 0.6600 in wake of a weak ANZ commodity index and broader Greenback strength having fallen from 0.6680 to 0.6601. Moreover, the Antipodean Dollars may yet come under renewed pressure amidst heightened RBA and RBNZ easing expectations due to the economic fall-out from Australia’s bushfires.

CAD

The Loonie is also doing quite well at the end of a turbulent week with Usd/Cad hitting a high of 1.3105 from 1.2956 at the other extreme, but currently eyeing bids said to be sitting either side of Thursday’s 1.3026 or so low. The catalyst for the comeback, better than expected Canadian jobs data with more encouraging internals after the dire update last time to end a dismal streak including Ivey PMIs, housing starts and building permits.

EUR/GBP/CHF/JPY

All on course to end the week barely changed vs the Dollar, but this belies the full story as the Euro staged another attempt to clear 1.1200 before turning full circle and a bit more within a 1.1206-1.1086 band, while the Pound rotated around 2 big figures from 1.3211-1.3014 and safe-havens tracked broad swings in risk sentiment, though not necessarily in unison or even with a lag. Not much if any reaction to data or surveys in the form of services PMIs, but Sterling did taken note of some unexpected/surprise dovish BoE speeches from Governor Carney and MPC member Tenreyro. Back to the Franc and Yen (and XAU of course), wtd highs were registered during the Iranian rocket strikes on Iraq bases used by US and allied forces, but no casualties and the calm response from POTUS prompted a sharp unravelling of war premia to leave Usd/Chf nearer 0.9762 than 0.9666, Usd/Jpy nudging 109.69 rather than 107.66 and Gold well below the 1610.90/oz multi-year apex, though still over 1550.

SCANDI/EM 

Somewhat strange, technically-driven and volatile weeks for the Scandinavian Crowns and EM currencies beyond the wider moves with underlying commodities, the Usd and changing market mood. Riksbank minutes and remarks from Norges Bank Governor Olsen did not really impact, but the Nok, Rub and Zar did track crude and bullion, while the Yuans are stronger on Phase 1 US-China trade deal signing anticipation ahead of next week’s likely event at the White House. Similarly, the Try maintained recovery momentum after local bank intervention, oil reversed early week geopolitical/supply-related gains and hopes for more CBRT rate normalisation next week even though Turkish CPI was firmer than expected.

subject: US EQUITY OPEN: Cash markets open flat amid futures dipping from premarket highs; ISRG +4.7%, NLOK +2.3%, NVDA +2%, TRV -1.3%, XLNX -1.2%, AAL -0.9%
content:
US equity bourses have opened little changed, where futures have been moving lower in recent trade and building momentum to the downside on the open. Participants are digesting the December NFP report, recording 145k jobs added, a bit below the expected 164k, whilst average earnings growth also failed to meet expectations. The lacklustre report saw an initial risk off spike/move, although was swiftly reversed, with analysts noting the Fed’s firm on hold position unlikely to be swayed from an individual data point. However, up to the open the risk off move gradually resumed, as the less rosy view of the labour market weighed on sentiment, also some participants may be eager to exit their positions after a week of fresh all-time-highs.

The data slate is particularly dry for the rest of the session, with no Tier-1 data: US wholesale inventory revisions for Nov due at 10:00 EST / 15:00 GMT and the Baker Hughes rig count due at 13:00 EST / 18:00 GMT

  • ISRG +4.7% strong preliminary Q4 revenue
  • NLOK +2.3% special cash dividend
  • NVDA +2% Citi’s top pick
  • TRV -1.3% downgraded at Keefe Bruyette
  • XLNX -1.2% downgraded at BofA
  • AAL -0.9% guidance lowered on 737 MAX woes

subject: Fixed and FX latest: bonds bounce briefly and Buck buckles after NA jobs data
content: Unsurprisingly, USTs led the knee-jerk debt upturn given a weaker than expected US payroll count and softer than forecast wages, while the Dollar rebound was derailed amidst losses across the board as the DXY retreats through 97.500 and Usd/Cad reverses towards Thursday’s circa 1.3025 low - Loonie benefiting from Canada’s labour report showing a decent recovery from the doldrums last time. However, it looked like Bunds were first to hit the curb and once the post-NFP buying ran out, sell stops and losses accelerated through yesterday’s 171.01 Eurex low to 170.85 (chart support ahead of 170.62, 170.42 and January 2’s 170.19 contract low).

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are little changed, as newsflow slows with NFP ahead
  • US President Trump said he thinks the US-China Phase One deal will be signed on January 15th or shortly after
  • China Global Times tweeted that a Phase Two trade deal after November is too far away
  • USD is firmer this morning, with GBP briefly dented by comments from BoE’s Tenreyro
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US & Canadian Jobs Reports

GEOPOLITICS

Israeli Air Force jets reportedly carried out air strikes in Al-Bukamal, situated in eastern Syria near the border with Iraq, via IntelSky - further reports note that the airstrikes targeted weapons shipments, via ELINT News. There were reports of casualties following the Israeli air strike, according to INTELSky citing Al-Maydeen news anchor. There were further reports of unidentified planes bombing the city of Al-Bukamal on the Syrian-Iraqi border, according to Al-Jazeera citing local sources – although it is unclear from the reports if this is a separate attack. (Twitter)

US House has approved the non-binding war power resolution which limits US President Trump's military capability in Iran. The measure would require Trump to cease military actions against Iran unless authorized by Congress or in response to an imminent threat. The passage in the House sends the measure to the Republican-controlled Senate. (Newswires) US Senator Graham notes that the US House passage of the anti-war resolution will not stop US President Trump from doing what he said he would do if Iran continues to engage in hostilities against the U.S. or our allies. (Twitter)

Iran govt spokesperson said reports that missile hit the Ukrainian plane is psychological warfare against Tehran. (Newswires) US National Transportation Safety Board has accepted Iran's invitation to take part in the investigation of the Boeing 737-800 crash, according to an Iranian official. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the US was ready to retaliate to the Iranian strike on Iraqi bases but decided not to upon hearing that no personnel were injured - Ohio rally. (YouTube) US President Trump's new National Security team was less cohesive and less inclined that its predecessors to push back against the President's wishes and are also less likely to consult with other administrations, according to sources cited by WSJ. (WSJ)

US Army is to increase their efforts to counter China by deploying a specialised task force to the Pacific, which will be capable of conducting information, electronic, cyber and missile operations against Beijing., SCMP; adding, US Army Secretary McCarthy is expected to announce this on Friday in Washington. (SCMP) Note, article does caveat that it is unclear how quickly the unit would be able to be deployed.

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac equities traded cautiously as the region failed to fully follow suit from the positive lead from Wall Street - which saw the tech-giant Apple soar in excess of 2% to a record high, after Chinese government data showed an 18% rise in iPhones sales in December. ASX 200 (+0.8%) was propped up by healthy gains in its financial sector with the “Big Four” Aussie banks all firmly in positive territory. Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was buoyed by its auto sector alongside other large-cap stocks post-earnings, albeit Fast Retailing shares slumped to the foot of the index after the Co. cut its FY outlook following dismal quarterly results. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp (U/C) were mixed with the former swinging between gains and losses whilst the latter lost momentum and gave up its mild opening gains before trading with little conviction. 

US President Trump said he thinks the US-China Phase One deal will be signed on January 15th or shortly after. (Newswires) China Global Times tweeted that a Phase Two trade deal after November is too far away and added that China's willingness to start Phase Two negotiations depends on the implementation of the Phase One deal; citing an expert close to the Chinese Government. Furthermore, China is not in a rush to begin Phase Two talks if US President Trump criticises the country during his election campaign, according to Global Times citing the expert close to the Chinese government. (Twitter)

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9351 vs. Exp. 6.9344 (Prev. 69467) - firmest CNY fix since August 2019. (Newswires) PBOC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position but a weekly drain of CNY 50bln.

UK/EU

BoE's Tenreyro says her inclination is to a cut in rates, in the event that downside risks were to emerge; adds that risks are tilted to the downside. More stimulus may be needed in the event that growth fails to recover. By all measures, the UK labour market is very tight; although, are signs that it is not tightening further, hard to believe this is the peak of the labour, expects further below target inflation. (Newswires)

UK House of Commons voted 330 to 231 in favour of the Brexit bill, as expected. The bill will now go to the House of Lords next week. (Newswires)

UK employers in December increased their number of new permanent staff for the first time in a year, reflecting a rise in optimism after UK’s general election; according to a survey by Recruitment & Employment Confederation. (Newswires) UK business optimism improved by the largest margin in at least 11 years following the UK general election in December, according to a survey by Deloitte. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European bourses are essentially flat, in what has been a fairly choppy session for the bourses; currently, there is no substantial under/outperformer amongst the European indexes. As newsflow this morning has slowed considerably, particularly on the geopolitical front, ahead of the US jobs report later in the session. In terms of sectors, the complex is mixed; notably, the banking sector is underperforming slightly (-0.4%) weighed on in particular by UK and Italian banks due to lower yields as Gilts and BTPs currently outperform their peers. Elsewhere, this morning other notable movers include Ryanair (+7.8%) after an update which saw them increase FY20 profit guidance; note, this update has bolstered the European travel and leisure sector to the top of the pile, as Ryanair accounts for 6.15% of the index. Just below Ryanair resides RWE (+5.0%) after, since confirmed, pre-market reports that the Co. may receive as much as EUR 2bln in compensation from their mandated exit of the coal-power business. At the other end of the spectrum price action is quieter with the likes of Uniper (-2.0%) and Travis Perkins (-1.7%) afflicted by broker action.

Amazon (AMZN) is said to be in talks to sell streaming TV ads outside of Fire TV and potentially to Apple TV (AAPL) and Xbox (MSFT), according to sources cited by WSJ. (WSJ)

FX

AUD/NZD - More respite for the Aussie amidst the raging fires, as retail sales topped consensus overnight to overshadow a sub-50 AIG services PMI and maintain positive trade surplus momentum from Thursday. Hence, Aud/Usd is establishing a firmer base above 0.6850 and the 50 DMA (0.6860), while Aud/Nzd has rebounded a bit closer towards 1.0400, as the Kiwi struggles to keep hold of the 0.6600 handle vs its US peer.

USD - Aussie outperformance aside, the Greenback is still outpacing the rest of the G10, with the DXY back over 96.500 and yesterday’s 97.562 high at 97.586 heading in to NFP. Note, headline payrolls are forecast to rise 164k compared to the bumper 266k tally last time, but could well surprise to the upside given mostly upbeat jobs proxies and a particularly strong ADP survey, so the Dollar and index may be able to extend their advances if the BLS report is bullish.

GBP - The Pound is holding up relatively well circa 1.3055 and 0.8490 in Cable and Eur/Gbp cross terms in the face of another dovish blast from the BoE, as Tenreyro shows tendencies towards backing a rate cut if the UK economy falters in line with Governor Carney on Thursday, and given downside risks amidst no further tightening in the labour market.

JPY/EUR/CAD/CHF - All on the defensive against the Buck pre-US jobs data, with the Yen slipping closer to December lows through 109.50 and bereft of any real option expiry interest to offer support until 110.20, while the Euro is back below 1.1100 to test the resolve of bids around 1.1090 that saved the single currency from deeper declines yesterday. Like Usd/Jpy, no decent downside expiries into the NY cut, but 1.1 bn in Eur/Gbp at the 0.8500 strike could buffer the Euro. Elsewhere, the Loonie has recovered some poise after sliding under 1.3100 following latest BoC commentary via Governor Poloz who contends that strike action and adverse weather are partly to blame for the recent run of poor data, but the impending labour update will be key in wake of the huge headline drop in November. Meanwhile, the Franc has retreated towards 0.9760, but faring better vs the Euro close to 1.0800.

Australian Retail Sales MM (Nov) 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.0%, Rev. 0.1%) (Newswires)

FX Expiries:

-        EUR/USD: 1.1100 (850M), 1.1140-50 (1BLN), 1.1175-85 (900M)

-        EUR/GBP: 0.8500 (1.1BLN)

-        USD/JPY: 109.00-10 (650M), 109.40-50 (800M), 110.20 (1.1BLN)

FIXED INCOME

Almost déjà vu at the core, as UK bonds inch over their post-Carney peaks (and Short Sterling futures better best levels as well) on the back of more BoE rate cut chat (from Tenreyro this time), but Bunds lag amidst an extension of recent outperformance in Italian debt and US Treasuries sit tight for Friday’s main event in the form of NFP. Looking at prices in detail, Gilts just printed 131.65 vs their German peer at 171.27 compared to 171.42 at one stage and T-note equivalent 2 ticks shy of the 128-305 overnight high.

COMMODITIES

A markedly quieter session in terms of geopolitical developments to end the week, with much of the focus now residing on whether the Boeing 737-800 crashed due to a Iranian missile; a possibility which Iran has firmly pushed back on but a number of nations, including US and Canada, regard this as a potential explanation as the investigation continues. Oil prices this morning are somewhat subdued, as the geo-political premium in the crude complex continues to unwind; overall, the moves are relatively small in magnitude as market focus switches to the US jobs report (full preview available on the Newsquawk research suite). Looking back on the week, WTI has printed a range of around USD 7.0/bbl thus far, with a similar range seen in Brent. PVM posit that yesterday’s price action, where the lack of attempt in oil markets to move higher implies that a ‘new status quo’ has taken over; which does tilts risks for price action to the downside. Turning to metals, where spot gold is down by around USD 4/oz and remains below the USD 1500/oz mark which was briefly reclaimed last night. Middle-East tensions aside, UBS highlight that physical demand for the precious metal is ‘tepid’, particularly from the world’s second largest importer India; although, overall they note the metals outlook is positive with the potential for a test of recent highs shortly.

subject: Nomura quants say equity speculators look eager to chase the market up again
content:
• Investor psychology on Thursday took on an even more bullish tilt thanks not only to relief over the de-escalation of the Iran situation, but also to high hopes for solid earnings from key American companies, Nomura says, adding that it appears to us that the market is letting itself slide back into a euphoric mood
  • Ultimately, global stock market sentiment only suffered a minor setback early in the week, after which it quickly climbed back into the zone above one standard deviation above its own one-year rolling average.
  • Going by the typical seasonal pattern in global stocks (the MSCI ACWI), year-end rallies that carry through into the new year tend to fizzle out and spontaneously reverse by 20 January or so. "However, there has been a relative lack of market-negative news, and investor psychology has remained quite optimistic," the bank writes, "against this backdrop, it appears to us that investors that had been waiting for a correction are now chasing the market up, having run out of patience," adding that "it may be that a spontaneous market adjustment that  would let pressure out of the system has been forestalled by investors willing to run the risk of buying the top."
  • The bank argues that, at a time when an influx of unfavorable news looks unlikely, the default expectation is that the stock market will eventually adjust downward as a result of speculative players paring longs. "As things stand, however, the major classes of speculators look eager to chase the market up again."
  • "It appears to us that the foremost concern in speculators’ minds right now is not the short-term risk of herding, but rather the risk of their managed funds underperforming the benchmark indices," Nomura writes, "this applies to both discretionary investors (a group for which it can be broadly assumed that investment decisions are made by humans) and systematic investors (for which investment decisions are typically made algorithmically)."
  • Nomura estimates that trend-chasing CTAs are adding to their aggregate net long position in S&P 500 futures at a furious pace, and that this sprint to chase the market’s upward momentum is giving rise to a systematic market melt-up.
  • The bank estimates that a hefty 47% of CTA long positions in S&P 500 futures were acquired in the brief time since the beginning of December, and therefore break even (on average) is seen at 3,245 in the S&P 500; it estimates that even fundamentals-oriented investors have adopted the bullish view and joined in the buying. CTAs' upward pursuit of the market looks likely to just keep gaining force unless the S&P 500 slips back below 3,245 in response to some shock or the uptrend hits a ceiling and CTAs start experiencing "buying fatigue"

subject: Newsquawk EU Mid Session: Friday fade in newsflow frequency, NFP looms - 10th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European bourses are essentially flat, in what has been a fairly choppy session for the bourses; currently, there is no substantial under/outperformer amongst the European indexes. As newsflow this morning has slowed considerably, particularly on the geopolitical front, ahead of the US jobs report later in the session. In terms of sectors, the complex is mixed; notably, the banking sector is underperforming slightly (-0.4%) weighed on in particular by UK and Italian banks due to lower yields as Gilts and BTPs currently outperform their peers. Elsewhere, this morning other notable movers include Ryanair (+7.8%) after an update which saw them increase FY20 profit guidance; note, this update has bolstered the European travel and leisure sector to the top of the pile, as Ryanair accounts for 6.15% of the index. Just below Ryanair resides RWE (+5.0%) after, since confirmed, pre-market reports that the Co. may receive as much as EUR 2bln in compensation from their mandated exit of the coal-power business. At the other end of the spectrum price action is quieter with the likes of Uniper (-2.0%) and Travis Perkins (-1.7%) afflicted by broker action.

FX

AUD/NZD - More respite for the Aussie amidst the raging fires, as retail sales topped consensus overnight to overshadow a sub-50 AIG services PMI and maintain positive trade surplus momentum from Thursday. Hence, Aud/Usd is establishing a firmer base above 0.6850 and the 50 DMA (0.6860), while Aud/Nzd has rebounded a bit closer towards 1.0400, as the Kiwi struggles to keep hold of the 0.6600 handle vs its US peer.

USD - Aussie outperformance aside, the Greenback is still outpacing the rest of the G10, with the DXY back over 96.500 and yesterday’s 97.562 high at 97.586 heading in to NFP. Note, headline payrolls are forecast to rise 164k compared to the bumper 266k tally last time, but could well surprise to the upside given mostly upbeat jobs proxies and a particularly strong ADP survey, so the Dollar and index may be able to extend their advances if the BLS report is bullish.

GBP - The Pound is holding up relatively well circa 1.3055 and 0.8490 in Cable and Eur/Gbp cross terms in the face of another dovish blast from the BoE, as Tenreyro shows tendencies towards backing a rate cut if the UK economy falters in line with Governor Carney on Thursday, and given downside risks amidst no further tightening in the labour market.

JPY/EUR/CAD/CHF - All on the defensive against the Buck pre-US jobs data, with the Yen slipping closer to December lows through 109.50 and bereft of any real option expiry interest to offer support until 110.20, while the Euro is back below 1.1100 to test the resolve of bids around 1.1090 that saved the single currency from deeper declines yesterday. Like Usd/Jpy, no decent downside expiries into the NY cut, but 1.1 bn in Eur/Gbp at the 0.8500 strike could buffer the Euro. Elsewhere, the Loonie has recovered some poise after sliding under 1.3100 following latest BoC commentary via Governor Poloz who contends that strike action and adverse weather are partly to blame for the recent run of poor data, but the impending labour update will be key in wake of the huge headline drop in November. Meanwhile, the Franc has retreated towards 0.9760, but faring better vs the Euro close to 1.0800.

FIXED INCOME

Almost déjà vu at the core, as UK bonds inch over their post-Carney peaks (and Short Sterling futures better best levels as well) on the back of more BoE rate cut chat (from Tenreyro this time), but Bunds lag amidst an extension of recent outperformance in Italian debt and US Treasuries sit tight for Friday’s main event in the form of NFP. Looking at prices in detail, Gilts just printed 131.65 vs their German peer at 171.27 compared to 171.42 at one stage and T-note equivalent 2 ticks shy of the 128-305 overnight high.

COMMODITIES

A markedly quieter session in terms of geopolitical developments to end the week, with much of the focus now residing on whether the Boeing 737-800 crashed due to a Iranian missile; a possibility which Iran has firmly pushed back on but a number of nations, including US and Canada, regard this as a potential explanation as the investigation continues. Oil prices this morning are somewhat subdued, as the geo-political premium in the crude complex continues to unwind; overall, the moves are relatively small in magnitude as market focus switches to the US jobs report (full preview available on the Newsquawk research suite). Looking back on the week, WTI has printed a range of around USD 7.0/bbl thus far, with a similar range seen in Brent. PVM posit that yesterday’s price action, where the lack of attempt in oil markets to move higher implies that a ‘new status quo’ has taken over; which does tilts risks for price action to the downside. Turning to metals, where spot gold is down by around USD 4/oz and remains below the USD 1500/oz mark which was briefly reclaimed last night. Middle-East tensions aside, UBS highlight that physical demand for the precious metal is ‘tepid’, particularly from the world’s second largest importer India; although, overall they note the metals outlook is positive with the potential for a test of recent highs shortly.

content:
ASSET CLASS FLOWS:

  • Equities: USD 0.5bln outflows (USD 11.6bln into ETFs, USD 12.1bln mutual fund outflows).
  • Bonds: record inflows (USD 23.2bln)
  • Precious metals: inflows past 4 weeks (USD 0.2bln)

Fixed Income Flows:

  • Record IG bond fund outflows (USD 14.1bln)
  • Modest HY bond inflows (USD 1.3bln)
  • EM debt inflows past 4 weeks (USD 2.8bln)
  • Record Muni fund inflows (USD 2.3bln)
  • MBS fund inflows 52 of past 53 weeks (USD 1.3bln)
  • 8th week of Govt/Tsy inflows (USD 0.6bln)
  • 4th week of TIPS inflows (USD 0.4bln)
  • 1st Bank loan inflows for 60 weeks (USD 0.4bln)

Equity Flows:

  • US: modest outflows (USD 4.8bln)
  • Japan: biggest inflows in 19 weeks (USD 1.7bln)
  • Europe: biggest outflows in 14 weeks (USD 1.7bln)
  • EM: inflows past 11 weeks (USD 1.9bln)
  • By style: outflows US growth (USD 2.6bln), US small cap (USD 2.9bln), US
  • value (USD 3.7bln), US large cap (USD 6.0bln)
  • By sector: inflows financials (USD 1.9bln), tech (USD 0.8bln), materials (USD 0.8bln), consumer (USD 0.6bln), com svcs (USD 0.5bln), hcare (USD 0.5bln), real estate (USD 0.4bln), energy (USD 0.3bln); outflows utils (USD 0.1bln).

TALKING POINTS:

  • “Maximum liquidity, minimal growth” explain bullish price action, ongoing leadership from high yield credit and US growth stocks (SPX/SPW, US/EM, growth/value, large/small all back at 2019 highs).
  • BofA Bull & Bear Indicator up to 6.5; BAML says investors most bullish since Mar’18 but not yet “extreme bullish”; “sell signal” (>8.0) needs USD 20bln flow to risky assets (HY, EM debt) next 4 weeks, new highs in HY vs. Treasuries, stronger rotation to equity cyclicals.
  • Meanwhile, new year consensus shifting bullish on liquidity (Fed/ECB/BoJ QE annualizing stunning USD 1.1tn past 4 months; global central banks cut rates 80 times past 12 months) and reduced concerns of recession, default, inflation in 2020.
  • BAML says it remains Q1 bullish but notes: this week sees record inflows to bubbly bonds; credit spreads (IG AA, HY BB) cyclical lows; equity leadership stretched (AAPL >40% above 200dma), volatility not at lows, investors have priced in PMI recovery >55 but no inflation (US wage growth>unemployment rate). Fresh gains on the back of goldilocks Dec payroll, Jan 15th trade deal, passive Jan 29th FOMC) should create peak bullishness and dovishness; we would recommend a “sell-into-strength” strategy should the 10-year yield move above 2.2% and as the SPX PE ratio approaches 20x.
  • As in 2018, BAML notes underperformance of high yield bonds (HYG), semiconductors (SOX), homebuilders (XHB), banks (BKX) should be viewed as a prelude to a “top”.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures return to or towards Thursday’s peaks
content: Somewhat unexpectedly perhaps, but in keeping with a grinding bid elsewhere ahead of the Liffe open, Gilts were marked up 21 ticks from yesterday’s 131.21 settlement price and have bounced further to 131.59, just a few ticks shy of their post-BoE Governor Carney speech high. Similarly, Short Sterling contracts have regrouped and probing higher again ahead of potential comments from MPC member Tenreyro and despite some upbeat post-election surveys overnight via the REC and Deloitte.  Debt and 3 month strips in general appear to have based or at least settled down after several big swings so far this week, and a broad downturn from lofty safe-haven peaks at the start when Iran launched its retaliatory strikes against the US.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 10th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Rockets reportedly landed near the Balad military base north of Baghdad, which houses US troops, according to Iraqi police
  • US government officials are now confident the Ukrainian Boeing 737-800 was shot down by an Iranian missile, citing satellite data
  • US President Trump said he might want to wait until after the election to complete Phase Two China trade deal; China Global Times tweeted that November is too far away
  • Asian equities traded cautiously, ASX 200 outperformed, Mainland China lagged
  • DXY traded in a tight range, AUD was supported by strong retail sales, energy futures and spot gold were uneventful
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US & Canadian Jobs Report, Chinese M2 Supply & New Yuan Loans and BoE’s Tenreyro

GEOPOLITICS

Rockets reportedly landed in the vicinity Balad airbase, north of Baghdad, according to reports. Iraqi police forces said the rockets hit near the Balad military base which houses US troops. US official said the military is assessing potential defensive adjustments after Iran showed it was willing to attack in Iraq. (Newswires)

Israeli Air Force jets reportedly carried out air strikes in Al-Bukamal, situated in eastern Syria near the border with Iraq, via IntelSky - further reports note that the airstrikes targeted weapons shipments, via ELINT News. There were reports of casualties following the Israeli air strike, according to INTELSky citing Al-Maydeen news anchor. There were further reports of unidentified planes bombing the city of Al-Bukamal on the Syrian-Iraqi border, according to Al-Jazeera citing local sources – although it is unclear from the reports if this is a separate attack. (Twitter)

US House has approved the non-binding war power resolution which limits US President Trump's military capability in Iran. The measure would require Trump to cease military actions against Iran unless authorized by Congress or in response to an imminent threat. The passage in the House sends the measure to the Republican-controlled Senate. (Newswires) US Senator Graham notes that the US House passage of the anti-war resolution will not stop US President Trump from doing what he said he would do if Iran continues to engage in hostilities against the U.S. or our allies. (Twitter)

US government officials are now confident the Ukrainian airliner - Boeing (BA) 737-800 - was shot down by an Iranian missile, citing satellite data. US President Trump said he has suspicions regarding the Boeing (BA) jet crash in Iran noting "somebody could have made a mistake. Iranian aviation regulator chief said it is "impossible" that a missile hit the Ukrainian plane (BA), according to ISNA. (Newswires) Iran govt spokesperson said reports that missile hit the Ukrainian plane is psychological warfare against Tehran. (Newswires) US National Transportation Safety Board has accepted Iran's invitation to take part in the investigation of the Boeing 737-800 crash, according to an Iranian official. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the US was ready to retaliate to the Iranian strike on Iraqi bases but decided not to upon hearing that no personnel were injured - Ohio rally. (YouTube) US President Trump's new National Security team was less cohesive and less inclined that its predecessors to push back against the President's wishes and are also less likely to consult with other administrations, according to sources cited by WSJ. (WSJ)

Libya's Hafta has rejected ceasefire request from Turkey and Russia, according to AFP. (AFP)

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac equities traded cautiously as the region failed to fully follow suit from the positive lead from Wall Street - which saw the tech-giant Apple soar in excess of 2% to a record high, after Chinese government data showed an 18% rise in iPhones sales in December. ASX 200 (+0.8%) was propped up by healthy gains in its financial sector with the “Big Four” Aussie banks all firmly in positive territory. Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) was buoyed by its auto sector alongside other large-cap stocks post-earnings, albeit Fast Retailing shares slumped to the foot of the index after the Co. cut its FY outlook following dismal quarterly results. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp (-0.3%) were mixed with the former swinging between gains and losses whilst the latter lost momentum and gave up its mild opening gains before trading with little conviction. 

US President Trump said he thinks the US-China Phase One deal will be signed on January 15th or shortly after. President Trump said he might want to wait till after the election to complete Phase Two China trade deal, but also said the US will begin Phase Two talks straight away. (Newswires) China Global Times tweeted that a Phase Two trade deal after November is too far away and added that China's willingness to start Phase Two negotiations depends on the implementation of the Phase One deal; citing an expert close to the Chinese Government. Furthermore, China is not in a rush to begin Phase Two talks if US President Trump criticises the country during his election campaign, according to Global Times citing the expert close to the Chinese government. (Twitter)

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9351 vs. Exp. 6.9344 (Prev. 69467) - firmest CNY fix since August 2019. (Newswires) PBOC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position but a weekly drain of CNY 50bln.

UK/EU

UK House of Commons voted 330 to 231 in favour of the Brexit bill, as expected. The bill will now go to the House of Lords next week. (Newswires)

UK employers in December increased their number of new permanent staff for the first time in a year, reflecting a rise in optimism after UK’s general election; according to a survey by Recruitment & Employment Confederation. (Newswires) UK business optimism improved by the largest margin in at least 11 years following the UK general election in December, according to a survey by Deloitte. (Newswires)

FX

DXY was contained within a tight parameter just under 97.50 and remained on standby for the key US labour market figures released later today (full preview available on the Newsquawk Research Suite). EUR/USD traded sideways and held onto the 1.1100 handle which sees around EUR 750mln of option expiries ahead today’s NY cut. Meanwhile, Cable experienced moderate strength as EUR/GBP gave up the 0.8500 handle to the downside. Elsewhere, USD/JPY held onto recent gains and fluctuated on either side of 109.50 throughout the session, ahead of its 100 WMA at 109.60 and 200 WMA at 109.70.  Antipodeans were choppy, the AUD felt some upside impetus upon the release of above-forecast Aussie retail sales, which prompted AUD/USD to briefly top its 50 DMA around 0.6860. The move was fleeting at the time but ultimately offered the AUD an underlying bid. NZD/USD traded sideways for a bulk of the session and retained its 0.6600+ status.

Australian Retail Sales MM (Nov) 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.0%, Rev. 0.1%) (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Energy futures traded lacklustre overnight amid a lack of material catalysts and as participants largely focus US-Iranian relations ahead of US payroll figures. Brent futures held onto the USD 65/bbl handle throughout the session after rebounding from its 50 WMA (USD 64.54/bbl) in the prior session, and with technicians eyeing Mar’20 contract’s 200 and 50 DMAs which reside at USD 64.22/bbl and 64.12/bbl respectively, with the two moving averages poised to converge. Elsewhere, spot gold posted modest losses and dipped below the USD 1550/oz mark before the yellow metal tested mild support around USD 1546/oz. Meanwhile, copper was little changed as the red metal balanced the prospect of a delayed US-China Phase Two deal with exchange inventories near nine-month lows.

CENTRAL BANKS

 

Fed's Kashkari (Voter, Dove) said he is not concerned about low rates causing corporations to take on too much debt, but is more concerned with banks holding the debt, wants to ensure they have enough capital. Kashkari added that business investment is low due to tariff uncertainty, where an improvement in trade tensions could support gains in optimism; doesn't see a recession in the next few years (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Voter, Neutral) said the 1.5%-1.75% FFR range is the "roughly appropriate" setting; sees between 2% to 2.25% growth in 2020, outlook has "firmed" in recent weeks, if anything. Kaplan expects unemployment to fall further and inflation rising to the 2% goal. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) said he is content where rates are currently, and Fed should assess the lagged effects of the recent rate moves. Bullard added that there is reasonable chance of a soft landing in the US in 2020 due to the fast growth of 2018 and 2019's risks; businesses are remaining profitable despite trade uncertainty. If tensions in the Middle East pushes up oil prices the US will be more resilient in the face of any energy shock. Bullard favours a standing repo facility as a long-term solution; wants to keep the balance sheet as small as possible and feels a standing repo facility would help achieve that if banks feel they can source reserves from the Fed as needed. (Newswires/WSJ)

Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dovish) expects that there could be no rate changes in 2020 and said if something happened that caused the economy to slow, that would call for a monetary response; inflation is anchored, maybe too low, doesn't see inflation leading to monetary tightening. Evans added that the US economy is in a very good place; expects employment growth to decelerate over time; sees inflation reaching 1.9% this year (in-line with Fed median dot plot), with current rates supporting inflation (Newswires)

Fed Discount Rate Minutes noted that all 12 regional banks voted to keep the rate steady; describe economic conditions as "positive" and were "optimistic about the prospect for economic growth". Several observe weakness in the manufacturing sector. Labour markets remain strong, with attracting new workers a challenge. On wage growth, the minutes note current and expected wage pressures. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy said inflation target must be symmetric, if the target is seen as a ceiling he notes they have less of a chance of meeting it, the target must be flexible and credible to households and companies, not only markets. (Newswires)

BoC Governor Poloz said it seems potential downside risks of the trade dispute have eased as the US and China approach a deal; remains to be seen if trade policy improvements feed through to economy recovery and investment. Poloz cited strikes and bad weather as contributing factors to the weak data; inflation has been very close to the 2% target and economy has been close to capacity for nearly two years. (Newswires)

US 

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 4 TICKS HIGHER AT 128-28+. The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Thursday. The session started off with a horizontal/downward bias, though a solid 30-year auction brought out the buyers. The auction itself stopped through the screens by a hefty 1.7bps, with analysts noting positive internals, where cover rose to a two-year high of 2.53x; dealer take-down was below recent averages, direct takedown was in line with recent averages, while the indirect bid was slightly above. Following the calming of geopolitical risk on Wednesday, which at the very least removes any immediate threat of military escalation between the US/Iran, and along with decent ISM services data and an ADP jobs report that surprised to the upside on Wednesday, the conditions appear to be in place to allow Treasury shorts to resume, desk noted. Some desks also suggest that rate unlocking in the corporate space has also added to the upward bias in yields.

Amazon (AMZN) is said to be in talks to sell streaming TV ads outside of Fire TV and potentially to Apple TV (AAPL) and Xbox (MSFT), according to sources cited by WSJ. (WSJ)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Tentative tone around the market amid looming US jobs data
content:
Asia-Pac equities trade cautiously as the region failed to materialise on the positive lead from Wall Street - which saw the tech-giant Apple soar in excess of 2% to a record high, after Chinese government data showed an 18% rise in iPhones sales in December. ASX 200 (+0.6%) is buoyed by healthy gains in its financial sector with the Big 4 Aussie banks all firmly in positive territory. Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) is propped up by its auto sector alongside other large-cap stocks post-earnings, albeit Fast Retailing shares slumped to the foot of the index after the Co. cut its FY outlook following dismal quarterly results. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp (-0.2%) lost momentum and gave up their mild opening gains before trading with little conviction – with the former pressured by its heavyweight oil giants amid recent price action in the energy complex.

In FX markets, DXY is contained within a tight parameter just under 97.50 and remains on standby for the key US labour market figures released later. EUR/USD and GBP/USD trades sideways with the former holding onto the 1.1100 handle which sees around EUR 750mln in options ahead today’s NY cut. Elsewhere, USD/JPY holds onto recent gains and fluctuates on either side of 109.50 ahead of its 100 WMA at 109.60 and 200 WMA at 109.70.  Antipodeans are choppy, the Aussie felt some upside impetus upon the release of above-forecast retail sales, which prompted AUD/USD to briefly top its 50 DMA around 0.6860, albeit the move was short-lived. Meanwhile, NZD/USD trades little changed and holds onto its 0.6600+ status.
